x to product y and in going from x to y there are actually three cost elements and they're
often lumped together in the case of green buildings and i think that's wrong-headed and so i like to take any
opportunity to debunk those myths so the first cost element is a learning
curve cost so i alerted alluded to that before okay so learning curve so
this doesn't have anything to do with the building right it enables the building to be
built but fundamentally this cost should be absorbed
by the folks who are going to benefit most from the learning which isn't the homeowner
it's all the professionals who are building their capacity as professionals

this is not about the house the second cost is
the other one that linda referred to and i'd say call that kind of the the green
increment or the bump in quality where you start in saying okay so let's do
green well what does that mean oh well maybe we should have a more durable roof
for example because all of a sudden we learn through this process that durability
matters longevity if you take a building and you make it last 100 years instead
of 50 well then you've cut the material impacts in half so that's an increment and that's based on
a decision to produce a different product so you can't really blame that on the
house either you've in effect changed your goal you've shifted your goal so it's no longer an
added cost it simply becomes part of the cost of this new product that you've decided to create
and the third cost is administrative so this is if you go after a certification
